editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: FEMALE PATRIOTISM OR THE DEATH OF JOAN D'ARC: AN HISTORIC PLAY, IN V. ACTS, By JOHN BURK—
Author of BUNKER HILL—PRINCE OF SUSA, and other Dramatic Picces.
NEW-YORK: Printed by ROBERT M. HURTIN, at the LITERARY PRINTING-OFFICE, No. 29, GOLD-STREET. 1798.

div.head: DEDICATION.
div.p: To that perſon in Ame • ica who poſſ •• ſes the moſt amiable 〈◊〉 , the moſt refined and engaging manners, the moſt lofty and ••• vated ſentiment; for ſuch 〈◊〉 I know—with whoſe friendſhip I have been bleſs'd and 〈◊〉 , and in whoſe eſteem if I did 〈◊〉 yet hold a place—I ſhould be unhappy—This play is dedicated w •• h as pure and fervent a zeal as ever offered ſacrifice,

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: BE not caſt down my Lord;
Fate has in ſtore for us ſome •• ighter hopes,
Which in good time, the genius of this land
Will ripe • into uſe.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: My deareſt friend,
How often have I liſten'd to thy hopes!
Day after day, when ills of every kind
Beat like a ſtorm remorſeleſs on my head;

At night, thy honeſt tongue beguil'd my care •
▪
And with warm fancy's glowing colours drew
The cloudleſs horizon, the proſpect bright;
Juſt as Aurora when with heaven's own tints
She pencils out the features of young morn,
Adds ſuch a bluſ • ing radiance to her ſtreaks,
That envious night withdraws her gloomy brow,
And leaves the world to ſunſhine and to day.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: Our fate is hard indeed;
〈◊〉 will not be ſo always; long enough,
The fickle dame has ſided with our foes:
She now will turn to us, while all her frowns
Will be reſerved for our enemies.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Think of an empire, waſted by the ſword
Of fierce inv • ſion; while the rancorous ſoul
O • pa • ty par ••• es all within;
O France, how •• ll'n art thou! o'er thy rich fields,
Whoſe ſweets and beauties may with Eden vi • ,
Roam 〈◊〉 the famiſh'd • ygers, or ghaunt wolves
The pirate ſons of Bri •• in's lawleſs iſle,
While we, the country's • rue and zealous friends,
Forc • d up and down with 〈◊〉 intrepid hand
Of honeſt Fr •• chm • n, ſcarce ſubſiſtence find.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: This is a 〈◊〉 , my 〈◊〉 , that melts my ſoul:
O would that ••• gundy, and 〈◊〉 Luxembourgh,
And all the trait • rous ſons of wild • ebellion
Were now to hear with me, theſe feeling words,
That, like me, they might burn with indignation.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Speak not of them my friend: they only feel
When tyranny and faction call to arms.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: My lord, I pray your pardon, if I uſe
The privilege your goodneſs has allow'd
Of ſpeaking truth; the fault is not in France,
But in the ſpecies; man is not the ſame,
The reaſoning, brave, and proudly generous being,
That in Rome's republic aw'd the world,
Or in the Grecian ſtates exalted man
As high in greatneſs as our mortal ſtate
Could well admit. In commonwealths alone,
We find this ſoaring dignity of mind,
That loves the vaſt and aims at the ſublime:
Where now in all this land to ſave his country,
Could we a Scaevola a Curtius find?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Thou'rt right my friend;
In monarchies the king is paramount,
And man is nothing: holding life itſelf,
(Tenure precarious,) on another's will:
The reaſoning being ſunk into a ſlave,
He drops his ſpirit's agency and moves
A mere machine: But where's the remedy?
Man blind to his own intereſt every where,
Like the degenerate Jew, calls out for kings,
He hugs his chains and is in love with bondage:
And were I now to lay my ſceptre down,
T' morrow they would raiſe another idol,
And bow before it.
But ſee my lovely princeſs comes this way,
My friend go viſit thou the frontier poſts,
And ſee the centinels be not remiſs;
I'll quickly after.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.p: 'Tis well, my lord.

div.head: SCENE II.—Dauphin and Mary of Arjou.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: How is it with my lovely fellow ſoldier;
Is yet thy tender ſoul grown ſick of war,
Or can'ſt thou look Bellona in the • a • e
And keep thy colour?

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: My ſor • ows • low not on mine own account,
B •• a • l for th • e, for thee, I love the camp:
'Tis thou haſt made the hideous front of Mars

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l:
W •
〈…〉 Mars and Bellona ſeem
Like 〈…〉 and •• be: from their lo • ks,

R •
〈…〉 drop the hiſſing ſnakes,
And 〈◊〉 roſebuds ſpring up in their place:
And 〈◊〉 the trumpet ſounds the charge to battle,
I take it for the muſic of a feaſt.
How ſweet • y doſt thou talk deſpair away:
I might reply, by ſaying that th • ſe wi • ds
Where now the ropes of France do lie encamp'd,
• eel 〈◊〉 their world of horrors and their gloom
Their pr • nce's preſence: do they not look gay?
Smi • e th • y not like ſweet gardens of delights?
Yes, all mu • t ſee they ſmile, or all ſee not
With Ma • y of Arjou's eyes.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Ah, heavenly fair;
'Tis all deception, all the charm of love:
They do not ſmile; they ſpread a frightful gloom
As far as eye can reach; killing delight,
Friend • y alone to adders and the wolf:
Puſh'd by the invader's ſword, by famine preſs'd,
In want of every thing, we here retir'd
As to a tomb to linger out our days.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Ah, ſay not ſo ſweet prince;
Why wilt thou drive the ſweet illuſion from me:
Ha! you weep: 'tis true enough, too true—
Theſe wilds a • e black indeed: But come, my lord,
Let us in fancy overtop theſe wilds
And think of future joys and palaces.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: O thou bewitching goodneſs;
With thee, my love, I ſhould incline to hope,
Tho' ghaunt deſpair, with death's head, ſhould appear
And ſhew his hungry form: 'tis thou, my love,

T ••
• o this cold and humid moſs doſt give
Its d •• ny feel; the wind thou tempereſt,
And by thy raviſhing converſe doſt enchant
As by a powerful ſpell▪ adverſity.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Let us, my lord, perſiſt and we ſhall yet
Be ſtrong enough, too ſt • ong for all our foes.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Would I could think ſo love;
But under heaven. I can ſee no means
To better our condition; hope is deſperate,
Pent up in woods our ſlender force doth lack
Raim •• t and food▪ and on their zeal alone
Do hold exiſtence. Enter a meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: My liege▪ I come the bearer of ill news:
The Engliſh troops, by fiery Talbot led,
Have gain'd our flank: and on the ſlender works
Like a wild torrent, burſts their headlong rage.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Hah! then theſe robbers envy us theſe wilds;
How long will heaven wink at ſuch offence:

Be not alarm'd my love.
Enter ſ • cond Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: 2d. Meſſ.
sp.l: My lord, the fainting ſoldiers call for thee;
Sore preſs'd on every ſide by hoſts of foes,
Indignant they refuſe to quit the field.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Heroic ſouls—they have been tried indeed—
But come, my love, let us our perſons ſhew
To the brave followers of our various fates;
Thy eye will rouſe their ſouls to new exertions.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I am prepar'd, my lord, to follow thee:
Self is extinguiſhed in me, and the glow
Of patriot ardor chaſes fear away;
Let's haſte, and place our perſons in the van.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Thy face will work more wonders than the head
Of dire Meduſa; that did freeze the blood
And turn'd to ſtone: thine all hearts will warm,
Will wake the ſoul to pleaſures and to love,
And make the fierceſt ſavage bow before thee. Exit.

div.head: SCENE III.—French camp and foreſt.
div.stage: An alarm; the French are beaten off.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Chaſtel, what haſt thou now to urge in comfort?
Our camp is forc'd▪ and Orleans our laſt hope,
The laſt aſſylum of our ruin'd fortunes
Is held in cloſe blockade.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: My lord I know it;
But yet to you and all this Spartan band.
Which thro' ten thouſand perils has preſerv'd
With veſtal piety the ſacred ſpark
Of Gallia's rights; to all, I do commend
Exact the ſame in • repid caſt of thought,
Which in proſperity diſtinguiſh'd you:
The warrior's ſo • l ſhould ne'er feel deſpair,
Or if it doth, it ſhould be the deſpair
Of fierceſt, bloodieſt, relentleſs battle.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: It's bravely ſpoken,
But ſounds too like a Roman for the times.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: It ſounds like Chaſtel, who in worſt of times
Dares think, and ſpeak, and act the honeſt man:

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: Reignier, what ſay you to this doctrine?

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.l: Here it may do;
Where th' open air's a court, and cave's a palace,
And lean and ragged chiefs are courtiers:
But in no court, where law and order reign,
Wo • ld ſuch aſſuming language be allow'd.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: The greater ſhame on courts:
It only proves there's ſomething rotten in them.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.p: Where's the prince Dauphin, I have news for him?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: Count of Dunois, thrice welcome to us.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: Methinks your looks are ſad, your chear appall'd▪
Hath the late overthrow wrought this offence?
Be not diſmay'd, for ſuccour is at hand:
A holy maid hither with me I bring,
Which by a viſion ſent to her from heaven,
Ordained is to raiſe this tedious ſiege,
And drive the Eng • iſh forth the b • unds of France:
The ſpirit of deep pr •• hecy ſhe hath,
Exceeding the nine •• b • ls of old Rome.
What's paſt, and what's to come, ſhe can deſcry.
Speak, ſhall I call her? B • lieve my words,
For they are certain and • nfallible.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Go call her in; but fi • ſt to try her ſkill,
Reignier, ſtand thou as Dauphin in my place:
Queſtion her proudly, let thy looks be ſtern,
By this means ſhall we find what ſkill ſhe hath.

sp.speaker: Reig.
sp.p: Fair maid, is't thou will do theſe wond'rous things?

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Reignier, is't thou that thinks't to deceive me:
Where is the Dauphin? Come, come from behind,
I know thee well, tho' never ſeen before:
Be not amaz'd, there's nothing hid from me.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Heavens! What tranſcendent brightneſs have we here:
What majeſty of mien, what warlike ardor!
And yet what virgin modeſty appears!
Does ſhe not look as if ſhe dropt from heaven!

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Say lovely maid, both who and what thou art,
That like a new diſcover'd 〈◊〉 appear'ſt,
Shedding thy rays on this be • ighted land?

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: My wit, untrain'd in any kind of art.
Heaven and our gracious Lady hath it pleas'd
To ſhine on my contemptible eſtate.
Lo! Whilſt I waited on my tender lambs,
God's mother deign'd to appear to me,
Wil •• d me to leave my ba •• vocation;
And free my country from calamity.
Her aid ſhe promis'd and aſſur'd ſucceſs.
In compleat glory ſhe reveal'd herſelf:
And whereas I was black and ſwa • th before,
With thoſe clear rays, which ſhe in •• 'd on me,
That beauty am I bleſs'd with which yo • ſee.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: Thou haſt aſtoniſh'd me by thy high terms.

sp.l: Not you my Lord alone, but all of us
She looks and ſpeaks like nothing we have ſeen.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Is it not Chaſtel ſpeaks;
Chaſ • el▪ the Dauphin's friend, and friend of man?

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Yes, angel fair, 'tis humble Chaſte • dar ••
To po • t his heart • e •• praiſes at thy feet.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Art thou that Chaſt •• ,
Who, in defiance of the wintry blaſts,
The b • rning ſ • n, and hoſts of murd'rous foes;
Doſt piouſly attend the ſad remains
Of murder'd freedom, from the poliſh'd hau • ts
Of ruffian government; and to the wilds

Reti • 'ſt like Cat •
▪ with parental care,
Foſt'ring the feeble ſpark of Gallia's rights.
D • ll form a • aunt!—And affectation die—
What need hath Joan • e P • cell' of diſguiſe?
Chaſtel, long have I in my humble ſtate
Been us'd to hear the praiſes of thy worth;
And when almoſt the tongues of all cry'd out
'Gainſt the looſe morals of the Dauphin's court;
They all were loud in praiſe of honeſt Chaſtel.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: The people over-rate my 〈◊〉 ,
If in the licenſe of unbridled rage,
Either in the rout that follows a defeat;
Or in the wild career of victory;
I've check'd the madd'ning tranſports of the troops,
And taught them to reſpect the rights of peace;
The praiſe belongs not to me, but the prince.
But if, by a conſtant life of ſervices,
I can deſerve the honor thou vouchſafeſt;
If by the ſterneſt practice of the virtues,
And • irſt of a • l, by cheriſhing the love
Of glory and of country; Chaſtel's life
Shall be devoted whole, entire to thee.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Then take this hand, I chooſe thee for my Knight
Wear in • hy hat this verdant branch of la •• el:

We •
〈◊〉
••• t ſide by ſide, and ſo will dare
That •• g • ted at our deeds, the God of war,
With his attendant furies ſhall retire:
As ſweeping down the van like thunderbolts,
We • o • the conflagrat • on of the ſight:
What ſay you Dauphin, Prince are we prepar'd

To mar •
〈…〉 relief of Orleans?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: Great maid, we're ready.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Now Britain tremble to thy iſland's centre;
And France, now let an univerſal ſmile
Like a bright ſunbeam, ſettle on thy face;
For now her glories end; and thine commence.
Come, let's away, and to the anxious troops
Unfold my ſacred miſſion, that their ſouls
May catch the glorious impulſe.— To Orleans.—Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.—Pavillion— Enter Dauphin, leading in Mary of Anjou. Joan of Arc.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: You both are virtuous, lovely, wiſe and young,
And worthy of each other. [They embrace.]

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: O wond'rous ſight! That one ſo young, ſo fair,
Should be ſelected to redeem the land,
By fea • s of arms—all beauteous maid,
My ſoul is fill'd with tranſport to behold thee,
And longs to imitate thy bright example.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.l: Princeſs. I thank, and at firſt ſight I love thee▪
For all its favors heaven has heard my thanks,
Be this among the reſt: In war, in camps,
Woman to woman is moſt neceſſary:
They ſooth each oth • r's f • a • s and cares to reſt,
By joint ſupport, and mutual confidence;
While their united dignity repels
The bold advances of a • dacious love.
[to Dauph.] My Lord—Has Chaſtel yet returned?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: I have not heard he has.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: Wh •• e has he been?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: I ſent him by 〈◊〉 lovely maid's deſire,

Wit •
〈◊〉 d • ſtance to the B • itiſh • amp.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: What if they ſhould d • tai • —perhaps deſtroy him?

sp.l: They dare not 〈…〉 !

A cl •
〈…〉
• d •• o' the w •• ld.

Come •
〈…〉 the order of o • r m •• ch:
That we may 〈◊〉 upon them.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: We 〈◊〉 attend you. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I.—Engliſh camp before Orleans
div.stage: Duke of Bedford, and Sir Jo •• Talb •• .

sp.l: What can this ſhouting mean in Or • eans?
It 〈…〉 beſieged 〈◊〉 .
F • r 〈…〉 uſe of chearing wine,
And 〈…〉 p •••• ce next to famine,
To break out in ſuch loud and boiſterous joy!

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.l: No leſs my Lord it doth aſtoniſh us.
Our faithful ſpies, wrap • in the ſhades of night,
Paſſ'd ſilently beneath the lofty walls
And heard the general ſound of exultation:
The muſic in the ſtreets, by warlike airs,
Recal the love of glory; while the roar
Of numerous ordinance, doth wide proclaim
The news of ſome ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: 'Tis rumor'd, that a courier hath eſcap'd
Our vigilance by night, and reach'd the camp:
Perhaps he brings the news of powerful ſuccour,
But be it as it may, we are prepar'd. A cry outſide.

div.stage: Enter a troop of ſoldiers, dragging in Chaſtel—The Earl of Suffolk at their head.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: Whom have we got here Suffolk?

sp.speaker: Suffolk.
sp.l: A Gaul, my Lord;
And to appearance of no common note.
We found him on the borders of our camp,
With one attendant; now then his eye
Did paſs enquiringly along our lines;
And ſeem'd to look the weaker quarters out:
Thinking my Lord, we might procure from him,
Some uſeful knowledge of the foe's deſigns;
I ſummon'd him to come within our lines:
But he, unheeding of my words, paſs'd on;
And frown'd in ſcorn.—Fearing his eſcape,
I ventur'd out with party of the troops,
And after violent and bloody conflict,
Wherein he fought with moſt determin'd valor,
We maſter'd him at length, and his attendant;
And brought him here, to anſwer to your highneſs.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: What haſt thou, Sir, to plead in thy defence?

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: I will not anſwer;
Until theſe blood • ound ſlaves of thine
Do take their ruffian fingers from my throat.

sp.speaker: Bedford
sp.l: Unhand him friends;
We ſhall find • eans to 〈◊〉 this daring ſpirit:
Who art thou?

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: My name is Chaſtel, and my country France
Which I do love as dearly as my ſoul,
And much as I deteſt you, Britiſh wolves,
Who with inſatiate fury prey on it:
My principles are, love of liberty,
And hatred and contempt of foul oppreſſion:
War's my poſſeſſion, and my object, glory:
What wouldſt thou more?

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: And wherefore art thou found cloſe to our lines?
And ſcanning them, as if thou hadſt been ſent
To find the proper pla •• s for aſſault?
The marks of ſtrong ſuſpicion are upon thee:
If thou remov'ſt them not, thy life ſhall be
A forfeit to th' inſulted laws of war.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Come hither friend, unfurl this banner ſtraight,
And let thy trumpet tell our buſineſs here: Trumpet ſounds
Bedford, look on this flag, by Charles ſent.
Under the ſhade of which myſelf I place Puts himſelf under it.
In thy deſpight; now touch me if thou dar'ſt!
Charg'd with a legate's ſacred functions,
Thy policy will ſave me, when thy rage
Had doom'd me to the tortures of the damn'd!

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: Then what the object of thy miſſion is
Quickly unfold, and take thy ſelf from hence:
For now the prophanation of thy tongue
Doth with reſentment tinge our royal viſage:
Speak, licens'd rebel!

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: I am no rebel!
'Tis not the man who ſtrikes at lawleſs power,
But the proud tyrant, who doth tread on laws,
On honor, wiſdom, liberty, and faith,
Who ſhould poſſeſs the ſlain of ſuch a name:
Ne •• a rebel was, as well as Cataline,
And greatly too, by ſo much as his crimes
Exceeded thoſe of him and other men:
You, too are rebels, who invade this land,
Becauſe you fight againſt the general will,
By force of arms, pulling juſtice down.
Now to my miſſion.—Quick convene your hoſt,
And tell them, that the proud avenging heavens
Whoſe vengeance, by a thouſand bloody deeds
Of murder, rapine, ſacrilege, and luſt
They've rous'd to vengeance—to the Dauphin's camp
Hath ſent a warlike propheteſs in arms,
Whoſe miſſion's object is to drive you hence.
Hear this and tremble!—'Tis the word of fate.

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.l: Hold Gaſcon—
And doſt thou think to fright the ſons of Britain
By ſuch audacious fictions?

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: By heaven thou dar'ſt not queſtion Chaſtel's faith
In any place but this—Follow me. Is going

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.p: Frenchman, I ſhall not fail. Is going

div.stage: [Duke of Bedford and Suffolk, ſtay him.]

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: Thou muſt not go—
Hereafter, thou wilt have occaſions
Enough to puniſh this preſuming G • al:
But now if by thy ſword he was to die,
The malice of the foe would call it murder.

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.p: My lord I am content.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: And well thou may'ſt—
For to this froſty plea, thy life thou oweſt:
But if thou art not now in fighting mood,
Meet me t'morrow at the Cave of Orleans.

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.p: Your hour.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.p: At the third Hour.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: Tis well.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: Hear, few words more before I leave the camp,
The Dauphin gives you three whole days and nights
To quit this land; but if upon the fourth
A ſingle Briton's found upon our coaſt,
He di • s tho' he had twenty thouſand lives.

div.stage: [Points to the Trumpet, Trumpet ſounds. Exeunt, at different ſides.]

div.head: SCENE II.—Cave of Orleans.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: O! Power ſupreme—
Thou univerſal ſoul of univerſe
Pivot on which do hinge the various ſects,
From the deſponding Atheiſt to the Sage,
Whoſe reaſoning ſoul demonſtrates a firſt cauſe
Now on thy ſervant Joan thy glories ſhed,
Give to this Spear the terrors of thy bolt,
When red with all thy wrath it hiſſing flies
And rives the mountain oak—Give me to rouſe
The ſlumb'ring ſpirit of this warlike race,
And let my voice
Loud as the trump at judgment day collect
All France to battle.
Who art thou
That with intruſive ſtep doſt force thyſelf
Upon my meditation.?

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.l: Think of a name,
Which of all others will diſturb thee moſt,
That name bear I.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.p: I value not thy name whate'er it be.

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.l: Thy face ſhall tell thy tongue it lieth—
Talbot's my name.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Think'ſt thou to fright the championeſs of France
By this bombaſtic ſounding of a name;
A paltry name, which e'en a dog might bear—
Talbot—Talbot—What's terrible in this?
I've ſpoken it—yet I live! Great Sir John Talbot;
Deſtin'd this day to ſcare the crows of France,
Not by thy name—but carcaſe—my ſword againſt
Thy name. Draws.

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.l: My ſword againſt thy ſword—
Heaven 'gainſt hell. They fight.
The conteſt is unequal—
For thou doſt fight with more than mortal powers.

div.stage: He is wounded and retires ſlowly, fighting.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: This is the place, the Cave of Orleans—
I have appointed Talbot where to meet him;
And now the hour is come, which we did name
To end our fierce contention by the ſword:
Thrice holy Cave—where e'er now Hermits paſs'd
In Patriarchal innocence their lives.
Now, for the firſt time, ſhall thy holy ways
Be ſtain'd with blood; now ſhall the ſounds of war
And accents of defiance ſtrike thy walls,
Which hereto, only echoed to the ſighs
Of ſorrowing penitents.—Pucella!
My lovely heroine wherefore art thou here;
With bloody ſword and thus enchafed too?
Thou look'ſt as if the mighty God of battle
Had blown his fierceſt anger on thy cheek.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: As in this cave I made my vows to heaven
With hoſtile ſtep a Briton burſt upon me,

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: His name? [With impatience.]

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.p: Talbot, he ſaid and vaunted proudly of it.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Gracious powers!—
The ſame I did appoint to fight with here,
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Wounded he lies within the Engliſh camp,
And had been kill'd, but that a hoſt of foes
Rous'd by his danger came at once upon me,
Juſt as my ſword uplifted high to ſtrike
Thirſted to ſtake its fury in his blood.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Would I had come a little ſooner here
This had not happen'd then.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.p: How! doſt thou envy this poor deed to me?

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: No, Pucella,
Tho' thy atchievments mounted on the wing
Of herald fame did ſoar ſo dazzling high
That Caeſar's deeds and Alexander's too
Compar'd with them, ſeem'd but the play of boys,
My voice ſhould be the firſt to ſound thy praiſe,
How ſhould I envy, who would give thee all;
But I do fear this Briton will give out
That I had ſent thee here to fight with him
Thus making uſe of ſupernatural powers
To keep my • elf from danger.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: He dare not ſay ſo,
Or if he doth, 〈◊〉 ſ •• ll to his teeth
Tell him tis fal • e and fight him afterward.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: Thou glorious female
Haſt thou no fears upon thine account,
Doſt thou ne'er feel the weakneſs of thy ſex?

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Chaſtel I will be frank with thee:
At our firſt meeting I did ſcorn • iſguiſe,
A thouſand different paſſions ſtrike my heart
Which frighted at the conflict they commence,
Knocks at my breaſt as if it would eſcape;
Sometimes the weakneſs of my ſex prevails
And I do ſhudder at the noiſe of arms;
And oft when I have ſlain ſome warlike chief
And ſeen life's current iſſue from his wound,
My heart ſeems broken ſo intenſe my grief,
And pity iſſues g • ſhing from my heart
As if the fund of ſorrow was a ſpring;
Perhaps I ſay this victim of my ſword
Has been ſome faithful lover whoſe return
His miſtreſs by the pureſt vows of love
Doth aſk of heaven; may hap a fav'rite child
The prop and ſolace of his parents age,
And then I think what tears his loſs will cauſe,
What groans, what ſorrow and diſtraction.
O Chaſt • l 'tis a dreadful ſtate of things
When tyranny doth force the good to battle.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: Thou firſt of women,
How all the virtues do unite in thee;
O wa • it but my lot to call them mine.
To ſay that I admire not thy perfections
The ſentiment which ſhines thro' thy diſcourſe
The delicate refinements of thy mind
The generous ardor of thy patriotiſm,
And all the virtues which have mark'd thee great
Thro all the ſtages of our country's bondage,
Wo • ld be to ſay 〈◊〉 had not eyes:
I like thy perſon and I love • hy ſo • l.
But we •• ſt not indulge a thought of love,
The very name m • ſt not 〈◊〉 h • a • d in France
Until the Engliſh be ex ••• l'd from it.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: Generous noble frankneſs,
In this confeſſion as in all things elſe
Thou keep'ſt thy greatneſs up, and like an angel
So tempereſt majeſty with condeſcenſion
That both are viſible tho' both diſtinct;
This ſword ſhall never reſt until it find
The time preſcribed in th • ſe words of thine,
Until the Engliſh be expell'd from it.
Come lovely maid, to Orleans be the word,
The famiſh'd townſmen throw their hungry eyes
Towards our camp and call on us for bread.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.p: This night the enemies camp ſhall give them bread.

div.head: SCENE I—A Foreſt. [Night march.]
div.stage: Joan of Arc. Chaſtel, Dauphin. Dunois, Reignier, with the French army, march acroſs the ſtage without beat of drum, Pucella holds the conſecrated banner in her hand.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Halt. They halt.
Now men of France be prudent and be bold,
Be ſilent as the night which covers you,
Furious as fire▪ impetuous as the torrent
Which thunders from the mountain to the plain.
After a long nights march we've reach'd the wood,
Where Britain lies encamp'd;
Now in your left the ſ • aling ladders hold,
Dauphin take thou the charge of the left wing
Whilſt Chaſtel and myſelf fight on the right.

sp.speaker: Dauphin.
sp.l: Let every Frenchman to her words attend,
There's ſafety in her counſel.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We will obey her.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Chaſtel to thee I do enjoin the charge
Of ſtorming Britain's camp; while I to Orleans
By famine waſted and by tedious ſeige
Do lead our convoy of proviſions.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: Great maid diſpoſe of Chaſtel as thou wilt.

div.stage: Violent thunder and lightening, the conſecrated banner is ſtruck from the hand of Pucella to the ground—The ſoldiers are ſeiz'd with panic—Thunder continues, Pucella preſerves all her fortitude ſurveying their fear with contempt and indignation.
Chaſtel holds his ſhield over her head.

sp.speaker: Dauphin.
sp.p: I fear that heaven is againſt our purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Reignier.
sp.l: It has declar'd its anger and we muſt
Be more than madmen to diſpute its will;
Let us go back.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: Was not the banner from Pucella's hand
Struck to the Ground. Pucella again reſumes the ſtandard.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: See ſhe again reſumes it,
And on her brow ſerene 〈◊〉 heavenly confidence:
The light'ning of her eye defies the tempeſt,
But beams reproachful on your daſtard fears.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Shame on you courtiers,
Did you ne'er hear the thunder roll before
That thus all motionleſs and in amaze,
With haggard eyes and frighted hair erect,
You ſtand like dotards prophecying ill • .
This thunder is heaven's ſignal to attack
The Britiſh camp, already half ſubdued
By its own fears and ſhrinking from the ſtorm.
Let's fire this thirſty foreſt and their camp,
And fall upon them choak'd with ſmoak and flame.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: The thought is great by heaven—
Let's quick about it.
What ſay you all?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Aye, let's about it quick.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.p: Then on to Orleans. Seizes a torch.—Exit.

div.head: SCENE II.—A camp and foreſt on fire.
div.stage: Engliſh ſoldiers run frighted in, purſued by the French.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Soldier.
sp.p: Which way ſhall we run.

sp.speaker: 2d. Soldier.
sp.p: No matter where provided we get out of her way.

sp.speaker: 3d Soldier.
sp.p: Tis madneſs and wickedneſs in our Generals to fight againſt the French who are aſſiſted by heaven.

sp.speaker: 1ſt. Soldier.
sp.p: As for me as long as I live I never ſhall fight againſt that holy maid again.

sp.speaker: 2d. Soldier.
sp.p: Did you not ſee how ſhe flew on our regiment? [A ſhout—Pucella d'Orleans— Long live Pucella of Orleans.]

sp.speaker: 3d. Soldier.
sp.p: There ſhe is, run, run. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Chaſtel and Pucella, driving before them Talbot and Bedfo • d.
Enter Dauphin and Reignier, driving before 〈◊〉 B • rgundy and S • ffolk.

stage.hi: (Firing of cannon, ringing of • ells ſhouts.)

div.head: SCENE III.—Inſide 〈◊〉 Orleans—Pucella planting the 〈◊〉 ſta • dard on the walls.
div.stage: Joan D'Arc, Da • phin. Reignier. Chaſtel▪ and Dunois.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Ring all the bells, and our artiliery
P • al to the heavens our grat • tude.
Cold prayers will not do: claſh on your ſhields
Thus we'll thank heaven.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: And after t •• e▪ heaven's lovely inſtrument.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: When we thank heaven, then doth this warlike maid
Receive our thanks: for is ſhe not of heaven!
Forbear my Lords:
Let not your praiſes taſ • e of blaſphemy:
I am no more of heaven than yourſelves;
Nor inſpiration do I feel, beyond
The ſtretch and compaſs of t • e human mind,
Devel • p'd by its own innate exertions,
No viſions had I more than one of you:
I ſaw no ſights but all of you did ſee:
France torn by feuds and foul diſſentions;
France deſolate beneath a ſtranger ſword.
I ſaw the faireſt kingdom on the earth,
The gallanteſt and proudeſt people,
And theſe my country and my countrymen,
Groan in the bondage of a meaner ſtate.
This only was my inſpira • ion:
And was it not enough—Forbid it heaven,
The tim • ſho • ld ev • r be▪ when France doth look
For a more powerful▪ ſacred call than this,
To ro • ze her to r • ſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: I could almoſt incline me to believe
In tranſmigra • ion; ſome mighty hero,
Or rather all the heroes do ſurvive
Within the boſom of this Amazon:
No ſingle ſoul hath merit half enough
To match her high perfections.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: And had you then indeed no ſpecial call,
No order, no communion from the ſkies?

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.l: No, no • e▪ my ſtory was a pious fraud,
To raiſe the fainting co •• age of the land:
If there be fault in it, O God forgive me:
I thought it not a crime▪ and hope it none.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.p: If this be crime, what will be virtue call'd?

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: By heaven 'tis virtue of the nobleſt kind,
Worth of the fineſt carat, leaſt alloy'd:
Her glory ſhines in her with tenfold luſtre,
In that 'tis all her own, her ſoul's conception,
Her ſoul did by itſelf become inſpir'd,
And lighting, by the exerciſe of thought
Within itſelf, divine enthuſiaſm
Did ſtraight communicate to all the land.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.l: My lords, our time is precious,
Now England flies and France is in purſuit.
When Peace invites to pleaſures on the lute,
And Mars reclines on his inverted ſpear,
We can diſcuſs what's virtue and what vice.
The trumpet calls to battle. Let's away. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV.—Engliſh camp.
div.stage: Duke of Bedford and Biſhop of Beuvais.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: What ſaith your grace to this intrepid maid
Whoſe valour ſo outſhines the braveſt deeds
Of our beſt warriors.

sp.speaker: Beuvais.
sp.l: When I do ſpeak of her I ſpeak in curſes;
But for her hateful preſence France long ſince,
With all its haughty chieftains and its prince,
Had low at England's feet for mercy ſ •• d.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: She certainly hath wrought us much diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Beuvais.
sp.l: And will continue • ſo to do
Unleſs ſome mea • s be found to take her off.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: Think you ſhe fights with only human powers,
Or hath the aid of ſome familiar ſpirit • ?

sp.speaker: Beuvais.
sp.l: 'Tis 〈◊〉 we repo •• among the troops
She hath 〈…〉 of ſome mal • ci • us fiend.

Loſt they ſuppo • e h ••
〈◊〉 is of heaven:
But ſhe no ſpirit hath but her high ſoul
To aid her projects.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: How then hath ſhe atchiev'd ſuch mighty deeds,
Being, as ſhe is, a ſhepherd's daughter.

sp.speaker: Beuvais.
sp.l: Within my dioceſe this maid was born,
And tho' her father was a peaſant ſwain,
She had a kinſman who was deeply read
In all the learning of the wiſeſt times:
This ſage did much affect the young Pucella,
And finding her of quick and ready genius,
From time to time, he did enrich her mind
With precepts good, and high conceptions
Drawn from the Roman and the Grecian bards;
And ſuch effect hath this upon the maid,
That ſhe applied the tyranny of Ta • quin
To our invaſion: and the ſtories told
Of Curtius, who ing • lp • 't himſelf in Rome;
Of Scaevol • , who aſtoniſh'd 'Truria's monarch
Into a peace with Rome; of Brutus, Cato,
To what ſhe might herſelf acquire in war.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt wonders to me.

sp.speaker: Beuvais.
sp.l: 'Tis even ſo
Oft have I ſeen her e'er ſhe join'd the foe,
Collect the wond'ring peaſan • s in a group,
With reaſoning moſt profound and ſenſible,
Explain their rights and duties in ſociety;
Deſcribe the crimes of tyranny and kings,
And glories which await the pa •• iot's name,
In lang • age • o ſublime and forcible,
That th • rule • h • ong ſeem'd borne above their level,
And I my • f 〈◊〉 ha • f incline to join

The D •
〈…〉 ſt • nda • d.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: T • was moſt ſtrange indeed.

sp.speaker: Beuvais
sp.l: W • c •• not hope to conquer while ſhe lives;
And 〈◊〉 we will try to take her off.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p:
H • w' •
• hat to be effected?

sp.speaker: Beuvais.
sp.l: 〈◊〉 and he • e.

W •
〈…〉 B • troops to flight,

And p •• n •• vi • tory d •••
〈◊〉
• or France,

To 〈…〉
• he of 〈…〉 unclaſp
Her ſhining ma • l, and ſh ••• es her awful ſword.
From her proud head ſhe takes the ſparkling helm
To wipe her glowing forehead: all the while
Heedleſs of danger▪ as if the enemy
Then is the time, if any time there be,
To ſeize upon her, while her dreadful armour
Lies here and there detach'd upon the graſs.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: The counſel is moſt wiſe.
But does not that hot Frenchman. Chaſtel,
Attend upon her cloſely in the fight?

sp.speaker: Beuvais.
sp.l: Elſe where we will draw his attention:
And for this purpoſe Talbot muſt ſtep forth
From out the ranks, and challenge him to combat.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: 'Tis good, it ſhall be done; we muſt not looſe a moment. Let your grace pray For the ſucceſs of our enterprize. The hour that ſees Joan de Pucella in our hands, ſhall ſee his grace of Beuvais arch-biſhop of Paris. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beuvais.
sp.l: I thank your highneſs.
Th • s have the bloſſoms of my fortune • ſcap'd
The withering blaſt, the cold and ruinous blight,
And the bow'd loaded branches of my honors,
Do promiſe ſtore of fruit. Had I remained
True to the Dauphin, and my country France,
The fame of my exceſſes and my crimes,
Had ba • r'd a •• hopes to my pre •• rment,
And my ambition, like a wol •••• rage,
Had prey'd upon itſelf. But join'd with England,
The weakneſs of whoſe cauſe does not permit
Nicely 〈◊〉 inveſtigate the lives of men,
While, in the licence of invaſion's camp,
My fav'rite vices have the wideſt field
And latitude for ind • lgence. To me therefore
The Engliſh, not my country's cauſe▪ is dear.
Come▪ then, thou bloody viſage fie • d of treaſon,
Th • t like a night- • ag, brood • d on the breaſt

O •• eeping 〈◊〉
▪ and to his gang
O • dark palefac'd conſpirators did give
The bowl of human blood, and bad them drink,
Put in my hand thy parricidal dagger:
I muſt do ſervice for my Engliſh friends:
If I take off this fierce heroic maid,
Whoſe proweſs ſo deſtroys and withers us,
I on a rock do build the Britiſh power,
And I, the architect, may claim reward,
Yea, even to ſurfeit. Exit.

div.head: SCENE I.—Proceſſion to Rheims to crown the Dauphin.
div.stage: The Dauphin and Mary of Anjou, ſeated in a triumphal car, preceded by a detachment of the French army, on one ſide of the car Chaſtel, on the other the Maid of Orleans, holding in one hand the conſecrated banner, in the other a drawn ſword; a band of muſicians; then follow the French army, with the count of Dunois, Reignier, commanding at proper intervals: After parading on the ſtage—
A ſhout, Long live Pucella de Orleans.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: And let my words prophetic of your joys
From Alps re-echoed to the Pyren • es,
Paſs thro' the land, and in its progreſs fire
All hearts with freedom. Shout, Hear, hear,
'Tis not to crown the Dauphin prince alone
That hath impell'd my ſpirit to the wars,
But on the head of every man in France
To place a crown, and thus at once create
A new and mighty order of nobility,
To make all free and equal, all men kings,
Subject to juſtice and the laws alone:
For this great purpoſe have I come amongſt you.
France is at preſent govern'd by a king
Becauſe that meek ey'd ſcience juſt emerg'd
From out the darkneſs of the middle age,
Where ſince the fall of liberty in Rome,
She mourn'd in Gothic chains the fate of man
Is known but to a few within the land
But when a thouſand ſages join their powers
To pour the blaze of reaſon on the mind,
The race of kings ſhall be but ſimple men;
The human race becomes a race of kings;
This may be call'd the golden age indeed. Shout.
Then on to Rheims, let's ſpight theſe Britiſh wolves.
The crowning of the Dauphin will pluck off
The crown from Britain's head. To Rheims—

sp.speaker: Pucella
sp.l: sola. My miſſion's done!
Orleans is ſafe and o'er the better half
Of this rich land the peaſant tills the ſoil
In peace and ſafety, while the ſhepherd leads
His flocks to f • ed or with the pipe and ſong
Renews Arcadia's pleaſures in our France.
All this my ſword hath done; what's yet to do
May be atchiev'd without my farther aid.
Why then remain I longer in this camp.
I feel tis not a place for me; For tho'
The love of liberty ſublimes my ſoul
And makes me do ſuch things to compaſs it,
As my ſoft ſex would ſhrink at; Yet I feel
Thoſe timid, ſoft, and virgin ſentiments
Play on the ſilken fibres of my heart,
Which ſpeaks me all the woman; let me heaven.
Sooner reſign my laurels in an hour
Than looſe one ſingle thought that's feminine:
This is the females jewel and of worth
More than a world; this it is which prompts
The modeſt ſigh the timid downcaſt eye
Which hangs the lids of ſympathy with tears,
And with a bluſh more lovely than the morn
Bepaints the maiden's cheek. My mind doth paſs
From the falſe glare of courts and dwells with joy
On the ſweet memory of my former life,
My rural cot, my lambs and ſimple ſports,
The grots that I have read in, and the brooks
Beſide whoſe margins I have ſeen the ſpring,
Decking the landſcape with ten thouſand charms:
Dear ſcenes of childhood I ſhall join you ſoon,
Soon ſhall I wind within your mazy groves,
Soon ſhall I mix among your a ••• ſs ſwains,
The d ••• companions of my 〈◊〉 days.
And help to bear the bluſ • ing vintage •• me:
But ſhall I bring my heart away entire?
No ▪ fa • the better part remains behind
With Chaſte • in the camp.
What news my friend?

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: Good if thou mean'ſt the preſent ſtate of things:
But if thou aſkeſt aught of future times,
News of the worſt deſcription is abroad;
'Tis rumour'd thou'rt about to leave us ſoon.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.l: The time is paſt when this were evil news;
Now France unwincing peers upon the ſun
Like the young eagle: fearleſs of the foe,
She doth refuſe not but demands the combat.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: Tis true dear maid
Our troops are now ſuperior to the foe:
But tis becauſe they combat in thy preſence.
Thou art the prop the pillar of our hoſt;
Go thou from us and we again relapſe
Into our former vile d • baſed ſtate:
Stay but a lit • le little longer with us,
Then with heaven's approbation and thy country's,
May'ſt thou depart. Do hear to me ſweet Joan,
Do not go yet, ſtay▪ ſtay a little longer,
And by the brightneſs of the ſun I ſwear
In hol • eſt reverence and in trueſt faith,
My life and fortunes to devote to thee,
To go with thee where'er thou wilt and live
The life moſt pleaſing to thee.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.l: What—if I put a crook into thy hand,
And bid thee drive the • po •• ive lambs to fe • d;
Command thee to reſtrain with pruning knife
The prodigal luxu ••••• of the vine,
Or wed its vagrant branches to the elm.
Wilt thou not frown and ſay •• ſe low born maid
This comes of marrying thee?

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: By goodneſs no:
But often as I view thy fa • e benign
And drink the ſeraph muſic of thy tongue,
With tranſport will my fix'd uplifted eyes
With hermit zeal give praiſes to the ſkies,
That they have ta'en me from the foul intrigues
The hoary cheats of Janus faced courts,
And given me back to nature. Fear not Joan,
Thy virtues and thy beauties be my ſurety,
Which if I break no Devil half ſo black
As I by ſuch a perjury.

sp.speaker: Joan.
sp.l: Thou haſt ſucceeded.
Let's to the camp and ſpirit up the troops;
One well fought action gives the war an end,
And drives the Britons to their iſland back.
To camp to camp and let the cry to arms
With voice of thunder rouſe the careleſs troops
To arms to arms.

div.head: SCENE III.—Foreſt and camp. (An alarm.)
div.stage: French drive the Britiſh troops off the ſtage.
Enter Beauvais and Talbot with Suffolk and a party of troops.

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: There ſits the maid of Orleans on the graſs,
And at ſome diſtance ſtands the valiant C • aſtel.
Now is your time call loudly on his • ame,
Flouriſh your ſword in proud defiance of him;
That when he leaves his charge to fight with you,
We may come on Pucella from behind.

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.l: It ſhall be done tho' ſomething whiſpers me
There's miſchief in it.

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: Fear not I do aſſure you of ſucceſs:
But do not call ti • l we are out of ſight.
My lord of Suffolk come—we m • ſt deſcribe
A circle round this hi •• . Talbot ſucceſs.

sp.speaker: Talbot
sp.l: calls. What Chaſtel • o!
He bears me no—what Chaſtel, turn about▪

Thou Gaſcon▪
〈◊〉 of Hyperb • le— What h • —
Chaſtel I ſay—he ſees me now.
And like the L •• ps 〈…〉 eyes with flame
And makes towards 〈◊〉 —Talbot 〈◊〉 thy ſoul
Stake all its powers on this 〈◊〉 fight.
What would'ſt thou have—By heaven 'tis Talbot's ſelf:
Thou'r • kind good ſir to point me to the foe
Whom of all others I preferr'd to meet.

sp.speaker: Talbot.
sp.p: This is my anſwer Gaul—Defend thyſelf.

div.stage: Draws—they fight and Talbot is ſlain.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: So periſh all the ſatellites of kings. A ſhriek.
A female ſhriek!—Good heaven it may be her's.
Far from the camp and unattended too,
I left her ſeated on the Loire's banks;
Wetting her laurels with the tears of pity
Which o'er the fate of thoſe deſtroy'd in battle
She ſhed profuſe—Another ſhriek!—You powers (another ſhriek.)
Protect Pucella till her Chaſtel comes. Exit.

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: My lord my lord,
Shall the fell deadly object of our hate
Whoſe deviliſh ſword has ſlain our braveſt chiefs,
When taken only ſ • ffer priſonment
The puniſhment's to • light for her • ffence.
Death only could have eq • all'd her demerit,
And lull'd our fears to ſleep. For while ſhe lives
The enemies belief in her divinity
Will live; they will give out ſhe is immortal;
That her impriſonment is endur'd by her
But as a ſhort and voluntary ſ • ffering
To purify and ſeaſon her to virtue:
A ſelf impoſed penance • rom the which
She may retire at will.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: All this I know: but where's the remedy.
E'en now the populace arraign our ſentence,
And ſcruple not to ſay inſtead of bondage
She merited a deathleſs wreath of laurel.

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: It doth not matter what the people ſay,
T'morrow they will be of other mind
And ſwea • ſhe richly merited her fate.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l:
How go we the •
〈◊〉
• he deed?
Haſt thou devis'd the motives and the means
Of this procedure?

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: I have my lord, and deeply as I think
Thou muſt confeſs. This Amazon my lord
As thou may'ſt hear, is much in love with armour
As Hannibal or Pyrrhus.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: I've heard as much, I know her arms did ſhine
In battle as they had been made of flame.

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: Not Peleus ſon with greater tranſport gaz'd
On the immortal armour forg'd in Aetna,
By giant Cyclops—when his goddeſs mother
Diſplay'd the ſpeaking wonders to his ſight,
Than ſhe upon her arms: they are her pride
And ſhe holds conference with them s'tho they lived;
Theſe arms were taken with her.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: Well what of this?

sp.speaker: Beavais.
sp.l: Can'ſt thou not gueſs?
While yet ſhe ſleeps theſe arms muſt be laid
Beſide her bed ſo as to catch her eye;
At ſight of them ſhe will forget misfortunes,
Fir'd by the memory of her former glory
She ſeizes them; all but her dangerous ſword,
Which muſt not be in ſight and puts them on.
Then—

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: Why then we being at hand with many vouchers,
Ruſh in and finding her with armour on,
Which we ſhall ſwear the devil help'd her to;
Will for our ſafety ſentence her to die;
As tho' ſhe had by witchcraft ſto • 'n the arms,
And wiſh'd again to perſecute the world
With ſorcery and war.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: Give me thy hand;
It is a well digeſted ſober plan;
Hannibal was but a babe to thee in wiles.
Go holy churchman let this deed be done
That we may ſleep in ſafety.

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: When time is older by an hour my lord
Believe it done. [Ex • t—at different ſides.]

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: Art thou ſure of this Dunois?

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: Beyond all doubt my lord,
Theſe eyes did witneſs her captivity.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: How! where did it happen?

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: Near to • hat quarter of the Britiſh camp,
Where John of Luxemburgh did hold command,
The Loi • e rolls his ſilver • lood along.
On the ſoft margin of this ſtream ſhe ſat,
Fatigued with victory and drown'd in tears,
Becauſe of thoſe whom bloody viſag'd war
Had 'reav'd of life; beſide her on the graſs
Her armour peice-meal burnt, her helmet here,
And corſelet there, and here again her ſword,
Beaming and blazing rays too ſtrong for ſight,
Like fa ••• ed P ••• ply: from off her lids
The pendent pearls Chaſtel wip'd away,
And ſometimes kiſs'd, ſoothing her troub'lous ſoul
By patriot arguments enforc'd by love.
While th • s employ'd a voice was heard from far
To call on Chaſtel's name. This voice was Talbot's;
A • rupt he left our championeſs and • lew
To where the ſound did come from;
There like a Mars arm'd at all points ſtood Talbot.
They fought: Talbot is ſlain; unlucky triumph!
Chaſtel it coſt his love, and France her ſtrength;
For while they fought a well diſpoſed ambuſh
Led on by Luxemburgh and warlike Suffolk,
Ruſh'd out upon her as ſhe wept i'th' ſtream
Unarm'd and unprepar'd.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: Was not the camp alarm'd?

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: It was my lord.
The voice of Chaſtel crying out to arms,
Did like the thunder pierce it thro' and thro';
Amaz'd the ſoldiers ran, they flew to him;
His tongue refuſing to diſcharge its functions,
He beckon'd with his ſword to follow him;
His eye did like an angry Meteor burn,
And on his brow grief and extremeſt rage
Sat equal match'd. Cover'd with duſt and blood
He urg'd th' purſuit, like to a furious hunter
Whoſe favorite dog or much eſteemed kinſman,
The lioneſs hath torn— Fruitleſs ſpeed,
The foe had got too much the ſtart of him,
And lo, deſponding faint and ſick of life
He now returns and with him the troops.
Drooping and faint and ſick of heart as he;
For all right well did love our championeſs.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Let's to his tent;
Methinks he much debaſes his high fame,
By loving with ſuch wild and paſſionate zeal
A ſimple ſhepherdeſs.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: My lord you much ſurprize me!
Is not this maiden rich in all the gifts
The brighteſt queen can boaſt; Is ſhe not fair,
Chaſte as the polar ſnow the which the ſun
Doth vainly ſtrive to ſoften with his ſmiles;
Doth not her mind almoſt by intuition,
Is ſhe not brave and to ſum all in one,
The Patriot ſaviour of this war worn land;
And haſt thou not often been heard to ſay
That virtue only maketh nobleneſs.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: No more Dunois;
The times do give a licence to men's tongues
Which wiſdom muſt reſtrain. Let's to his tent. Exit

div.head: SCENE I.—A Priſon.
div.stage: Pucella diſcovered ſleeping on a wretched truckle bed—a loaf of bread and a pitcher of water on a table—Engliſh ſilently enter and lay her armour near her and retire—She awakes and ſeizes her arms with delight and aſtoniſhment.
div.l: You ſplendid partners of Pucella's fame,
Has the Almighty dropt you from the ſkies,
Or on the wing of Angel are you borne.
To chear my ſight. Takes up the Corſlet.
Again this corſlet,
'Gainſt which my heart did heave as if t'would burſt
The claſps aſunder: on my breaſt ſhall ſhine,
And b • a •• ng fiercely as the torrid ſun,
Like to Meduſa's Gorgon head ſhall turn
Britons to ſtone and wither all their rage.
Faithful ſhield
Which oft Pucella guarded from the foe,
As if a ſaint did watch at every claſp;
Where are thoſe glorious ſpots of hoſtile blood,
Which ting'd thy boſs: when from the burning war
The haughty Talbot, like a wounded boar
Foaming with pain and madneſs ſlow retir'd,
Grinding his teeth; while from his blood-ſhot eyes
Shame and confuſion to be ſo ſubdued
Shot balefully—here's one, and here, and here;
But where's my ſword;
Where is the flaming blade which from this hand
Lighten'd and thunder'd on the trembling foe
As if it rain'd a ſhower of ſparkles on them.
div.stage: Enter the biſhop of Beauvais, goaler and guards.

sp.speaker: Beauvais.
sp.l: Ha trait'reſs; at thy old pranks again?
Still working ſpells and muttering incantations;
Lay hold on her and bow her ſtubborn neck
Down to the earth with fet • ers.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Stand off baſe ſlaves,
Or by the ſhade of Brutus I will tear
Your coward ſo • ls out: am I then ſo chang'd,
Is there not left one ſingle • ay of glory
To ſtrike you to the earth baſe runaways,
Whom I have oft purſued like frighted deer.
And thou vile Monk, (To Beauvais.)
What hi • ders from my priſon, but I wrench
Some b •• or bar and da •• thy ſkull to ſhivers!
Juſtice and France demand it and you die.
sp.stage:
Sh • r • ſhes to the priſon windows and wrenches by force an iron bar—b •• k▪ mortar and ſplinters of wood follow— Beauvais and ſoldiers retire with precipitation—goaler falls
on his knees—Pucella holds the bar lifted over him in the attitude of ſtriking.
sp.l: Riſe wretch, To the goaler.
Thou barely doeſt thy duty; take thy life
And when the wretched tenants of this manſion
Cry out to thee for mercy; bear in mind
Thyſelf had dy'd but for it. (Goaler goes off trembling.)

sp.speaker: Pucella sola.
sp.l: Now comes the trial of my fortitude,
Now will theſe butchers tear my tender body,
Now will my enemies with ſavage joy,
With bloody hands and eyes of murd'rous gaze
Preſent themſelves to me: O ſhield me heaven,
Thou guardian of the innocent ſtand forth
And ſave me from their fury: ha they come,
There ſtands the horrid rack to torture me,
There come the executioners: avaunt
Ruffians; take from my ſight thoſe cut-throat eyes,
Dare you to kill the championeſs of France?
Ah Pucella,
Where is the conſtancy which buoy'd thee up
And bore thee thro' the thunder of the fight,
When all the grander virtues fir'd thy ſoul
And forc'd into thy cheeks ſuch blaze of valour
That f • ar dar'd not approach thee; but retir'd
Into the ranks of Britain: 'tis gone—'tis fled;
And 'tis but natural it ſhould be gone;
Remov'd from thoſe I love, and fall'n alive
Into the power of my bittereſt foes;
No friendly hand to cloſe my dying eyes,
No pitying voice to ſooth the pang of torment:
But fiends on every ſide, and murderers
Glaring with cannibal impatience on me:
The ſtouteſt heart would tremble in ſuch moment.
You gracious powers if with pure intent
I fought • o reſcue France from bondage,
Hear now a • d exec • te Pucella's 〈◊〉 :
Blow in my ſoul the fury of the • yger,
The conſtancy in ſuffering of the wolf,
Who • tter • not a cry tho' the fierce dogs
Rend him to pieces; the leopard's fierceneſs,
And all the horrid properties of rage
Collected from the boſoms of wild beaſts:
Encaſe my heart in ſteel, and o'er my face
Breathe ſuch a ſpirit as will make it calm
Amidſt the ſhocks of agonizi • g pain:
Between it and my body ſtop all intercourſe,
That when Pucel • a feels the pangs of death,
Her viſage may not tell i • to the foe. [riſes.]

div.stage: Enter Duke of Bedford. Earl of Suffolk, Biſhop of Beauvais▪ with guards.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.p: If ſhe makes the leaſt reſiſtance hew her to pieces▪ and do thou holy biſhop ſtand by with your breviary open in yo •• hand—and crucifix, leſs any evil ſpirits come to her aſſiſtance—advance upon her guards—perdition on yo • r daſtard ſouls do you ſtand—Give me a ſpear—ſnatches a ſpear from the next to him—Pucella takes up the bar—he keeps at diſtance.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.l: Tyrant advance,
That Sampſon like my laſt atchievement
May far o • tſhine the actions of my •• fe.

sp.speaker: Bedford.
sp.l: Sorcereſs attend and • ear thy ſentence read.
Read Beauvais.

sp.speaker: Beauvais
sp.p: reads. Thou Joa • de Pucella, commonly call'd Joan of Arc or Pucella of Orlea • s, convicted before us on good and poſitive evidence of ſorcery and witchcraft; ſhall be taken to the market place of Rouen. where thou ſhalt be tied to a ſtake, thy body burnt, and the aſhes thrown into the ſea.

sp.speaker: Pucella.
sp.p: O Heaven.! [Falls lifeleſs into the arms of ſoldiers, and the ſcene cloſes.]

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Accept the only comfort I can give;
Sorrow • hat ſa •• y keeps •• ce with thy ſorrows,
And ſympathy which makes thy griefs my own.

sp.speaker: Chaſt.
sp.l: My 〈◊〉 and 〈◊〉 my lords. I thank you much,

Indeed I do no • m •
〈…〉 you grieve;
The loſs was your 〈◊〉 France's much as mine,
I rather wonder that we do outlive
The death of all our flattering proſpects:
We ſee the glorious temple of our rights
Whoſe ſpires encircled by the ſun gilt clouds
Enroll'd our infant honors in the ſkies
Ready to tumble down and bury us
Beneath its ruins. Think my lords,
O think upon the treaſure we have loſt,
Think on her valour, it is loſt to us,
Her heavenly confidence 'tis loſt to us,
Her ready genius, cool deliberate mind,
Think of her angel face, her mild demeanor.
The ſtreams of fire which lighten'd in her eyes,
When ſhe did lead our troops againſt the ſee;
And think, O think they all are loſt to us.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: With grief and wonder we reflect on them;
She was indeed all thou haſt ſaid of her.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: Wilt thou not try to ſave her then?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: I know not how to ſave her.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: Haſt thou not thought on it?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: I have not.

sp.l: Not thought on it, not once? It cannot be
The wearing of a crown ſ •• uld ſo free • up
Fair nature's mi • ky workings in the heart.
Not think on her who gave thee life at Orleans,
A crown at 〈…〉 and victory every where:
Who dr • ve thy fo • s b • fore, 〈…〉 thee,
And ſhew • d 〈◊〉 way with 〈◊〉 fl • wers of hope.
O 〈…〉 ! O 〈◊〉 to faith!

Falſe R •
〈…〉 ,
For who did ever 〈◊〉 a of 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: 〈…〉 all this?

sp.l: Say, 〈…〉 an embaſſy t'the foe,
To 〈◊〉 about the 〈◊〉 ſom of this maid?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: I have not.
No • m • a •• ſt to do • t?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l:
M •••
〈◊〉 'twould 〈◊〉 become our royal ſtate
To ſend a ſage a • d 〈…〉 embaſſy.
To bear the 〈◊〉 of a 〈…〉 .

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: And why did not your royalty diſdain
To be enthroned by this peaſant maid?
Why not your royal head refuſe the crown
Your hand the ſceptre ſpurn when proferr'd by,
When like an angel in the robes of war,
On foot▪ bareheaded▪ near your royal car,
She led your glittering cavalcade to Rheims,
Safe through the enemy's confines? Royal Sir,
Reſolve theſe queſtions.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: Knoweſt thou to whom thou ſpeakeſt?

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Art thou not he who la • e with cap • n hand
Did court the favour of the loweſt kind?
That ſtrikes with wooden ſhoe the ſoi • of France?
Who woo • d all orders of the ſtate with ſm •• es?
Who talk'd of freedom and the rights of man?
Who eulogiz'd Republics by the hour?

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p:
Inſolent ſlave!
[Draws his ſword, is diſarmed by the L •• ds.]

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Tiberius was a Saint e're he was an emperor,
The empire did transform him to a devil.
France hang thy head, a Nero is thy king.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.p: Chaſtel retire.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: My Lords caſt not away your fears on me,
I will not ſtir, I care not for his anger;
I too am angry and I muſt be heard;
Chaſtel is always arm'd within himſelf,
For every varying change of Proteus fortune,
This is my ſafety. (Draws his ſword.)
Which if it fail to avenge me on my foes,
Shall yet do juſtice for me on myſelf.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: By your allegiance Lords I do command you,
Take him to execution.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Why this is ſpoken like a royal king.
To execution—this muſt ſure convince,
At leaſt it is concluſive for 'tis laſt,
And we may know the Monarch's logic ſpent.
When he doth give his ultima ratio.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: Nay then you muſt retire,
For you do pull your ruin on your head.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Take him away—
Are you all leagued againſt me—Go, Reignier,
Summon my guard, give the wide camp alarm;
Te • l them▪ foul traitors meditate to kill
The Lord's anointed—What guards, ho!

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: What guards, ho! (ſtamps with his foot— Guards enter.)
Why came you not before.
My faithful •• hort, dear Praetorian band,
Sweet Ja •• zaries▪ come, your monarch trembles,
Your Sophy's, Cal • p • 's, royal Sultan's pale,
Becauſe that wicked Chaſtel tells him truth;
Come, ſabre me this Chaſtel out of hand;
Come ſlice me off his head.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: By heaven the villain mocks me;
Give me a ſword.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: Do you not hear?—bring Hercules a diſtaff.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Take him out.
(Guards whiſper to each other •

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.p: Why talk you thus apart—take him away.

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: My gracious Lord,
The ſoldiers with all loyal due reſpect,
Bid me declare they will not ſuffer Chaſtel
The ab • eſt, deareſt general in the land,
The friend and lover of their loved Joan,
The firmeſt patriot and their trueſt friend,
To live in bonds, or die a traitors death.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Here there is no ingratitude; generous ſouls,
Worthy to live in the beſt days of Rome,
I know not how to thank you.
Which in this fair and honorable meeting,
Is count Chaſtel.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: What of him—in me you ſee that Chaſtel.

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: Indeed my tidings have a wider import
Than thy particular ſphere will comprehend;
All France they do concern.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: The ſtrength, the intereſt and the power of France▪
Thou ſee'ſt before thee.

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.p: But thee it moſt and neareſt doth concern.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: I wait to hear it.

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: Then ſummon all thy courage to thy aid,
Make hard thy heart by thinking on the worſt,
The bloodieſt, felleſt▪ blackeſt tidings,
Thy ear can tell thy ſoul.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Well—

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: Suppoſe the lares of your parents' houſe
Stained with your parents' •• ood,
Your general kin ſlain by the murderer's knife.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Death, why do you keep me thus upon the rack,
Out with thy tidings.

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: The ſun of France is ſet:
Fair Virtue's mirror, Beauty's peerleſs paragon,
Great Freedom's Saint, and Glory's glorious model,
That beſt epitome of all the virtues,
The beauteous Joan, our Championeſs is dead.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: Dead didſt thou ſay?

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: Ay, dead, dead, dead.
Oftener than I have breath to tell it thee,
I have died to think on it.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: O heaven, it was too ſoon,
Fell Death, thou king, thou ugly tyrant,
Were there not perjur'd wretches on the earth,
Murderers enough and th • eves of wolfiſh natures,
Oppreſſors of the poor▪ foes of the orphan,
Had not the ſtroke been better arm'd at them:
Were there not king • —

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: Better the altars of the foe had ſtream'd
With choiceſt blood of twenty thouſand French,
Than this one Heroine die.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Is this undoubted, is there left no room
For chance to work a bleſſing.?

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: Theſe eyes that now look on you ſaw her die;
Theſe eyes beheld her girt around with flames,
Which her • e • y mounting ſeem'd to threaten heaven
With conflagration; She mean while,
Like a pure ſpirit, 'rayed in robes of flame,
Seem'd ready to aſcend unto the ſkies;
Some gentle ſpirit ſat upon her face,
Arming it with patience and benignant ſmiles,
For when the curling ſmoak and crackling flames
Puſh'd by the ingruous breeze, did backward roll,
Her beauteous vi • age, like the radiant ſun
Breaking thro' angry clouds did ſhew itſelf
Placid, and bright, and undefil'd by grief;
O God, there was a ſight would arm the land,
From end to end and give the mighty maſs
Order, and courage, and enthuſiaſm,
And drive them on the Engliſh.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: Some great avenger from her aſhes riſe.
Behold good Sir, how dearly ſhe was lov'd,
The aſſembly's drown'd in tears.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: What all in tears, and not one briny drop
Will ſhew itſelf upon my ſavage lids.—
Doth the King weep too?

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.p: You ſee he weeps my Lord.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: And did the Engliſh ſoldiers mourn her fate.

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: They did my Lord, not a dry eye did look
Upon her execution. Bedford except,
And Traitor Beuvais, and two other lords,
Whoſe Tyger ſouls did never know remorſe.
All wept as if a dear relation died.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: And why am I ſo like theſe bloody Caiti •• s,
That my fierce orbs refuſe a ſingle tear:
By heaven▪ I lov'd her more 〈◊〉 all of you,
A hundred thouſand eyes could not rain out
So true a ſorrow as my boſom feels;
My ſoul is parch'd, it burns and is conſum'd
By all the waſting bitterneſs of woe.
And yet I cannot weep.

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Be it ſo, 'tis well;
The fever of my fury eats them up,
As the hot ſun doth burn the ex • alations.
Let ſorrow go and vengeance take • s place
Bedford and Beuvais ſhall ſhed tears of blood.

sp.speaker: Citizen.
sp.l: My Lord,
This ſealed paper did the holy maid
Deliver to my hands with ſtrong injunction
To give it none but you. Chaſtel ſnatches it and reads.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.p: [kiſſes it.] It is the well known hand—take it Dunois
I cannot read.

Dunois reads. To Chaſtel beloved by her above all things, next to her country and her God, Joan of Arc bids a laſt farewell. The Engliſh have condemn'd me to be burnt, horrible death, cruel and ſanguinary enemies—Weep not for me my friend, my death will be a laſting reproach to my enemies, and will cover me with glory. I have ſerv'd France and the Dauphin with the trueſt and holieſt zeal.—The indiffer •••• of the latter to my ſituation, proves only, what the expe •••• ce of all ages had before confirmed, that there is neither faith, juſtice, or gratitude in kings—You are however conjured by your eſteem and love of me, to ſacrifice your reſentment to the general good—my fate will touch his heart—He will weep for me—I forgive him—unite to chaſe the Engliſh from France—Monarchy for ſome time longer will be the government of it, but the time will be when every veſtige of it will diſappear, your country will one day become a mighty Republic, in the glory and immenſity of which all former governments will be loſt.—A virtuous band of Engliſh coloniſts, whoſe love of freedom forc'd them to imigrate to a vaſt unknown land beyond the great waters, ſhall firſt throw down the gauntlet to Kings, and overturn the throne of their tyrant—France will follow her example: ſhall overturn all thrones, and exterminate all tyrants. The nations of the earth will forget their former antipathies: Even England ſhall ſtretch out the arm of friendſhip to France—This letter is the ſubſtance of a viſion, and I almoſt pronounce it prophecy. My ſufferings will give you courage and reſentment—Farewell.

sp.speaker: Meſſ.
sp.l: The Duke of Bedford's dead.
Haunted both night and day by guilty 〈◊〉 ,
And by remorſe, 'tis ſaid, for murder'd Joan:
Diſeaſe and ſickneſs came ſo faſt upon him
That he had hardly time to ſay farewell.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: By heaven I'm ſorry for it,
This ſword ſhould have let out his caitiff blood.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: 'Tis as it ſhould be.
Heaven will not be depriv'd of its revenge.

sp.speaker: 2. Meſſ.
sp.l: The traiterous prelate Beauvais is no more.
An awful viſion robbed him of his reaſon,
His bloody hand did juſtice on himſelf.

sp.speaker: Dunois.
sp.l: Another victim of the wrath of God;
You ſee how heaven combats on our ſide.
Let the laſt words of that departed ſaint
Be freſh upon your minds. Frenchmen unite,
Forſwear all priva • e quarrels and diſſenſions,
And let our ſolid undivided power
Fall like a mountain on the Engliſh ranks.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Dunois, thy words as from a lethargy
Arouſe my wandering ſpirits; the fainted maid,
The aſ • es of whoſe precious body fly
On the wild winds, perhaps now o'er our heads
She did forbid diſſ •• ſions.

sp.speaker: Dauph.
sp.l: Be witneſs for me Heaven,
How gladly would I lay my ſceptre down
To bring her back to life.

sp.speaker: Chaſtel.
sp.l: Indeed? Then I,
Fo • lowing her noble nature, do forgive,
And God forgive thee too. Frenchmen to arms,
Gird on your ſwords, and put your armour on.
The ſpirit of the lovely Joan of Arc,
Doth hover o'er the field, and ſhrieks for vengeance.

div.p: ☞ Thirty lines of the firſt Act, are taken verbatim from Shakeſpeare's Henry VI.—The ſubſtance of the ſcene was nece •• ary, and the Author was apprehenſive of getting into his ſentiments, perhaps his words.
